questions.question: A car accelerating at a constant rate of $3.2\,\text{m/s}^2$ reaches a speed of $24\,\text{m/s}$ in $5.0\,\text{s}$. Calculate the initial velocity of the car.
questions.explanation: Using the kinematic equation $v_f = v_i + at$, we have $24 = v_i + 3.2(5) = v_i + 16$. Solving gives $v_i = 8\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: An airplane requires a takeoff speed of $85\,\text{m/s}$. If the runway available is $1.2\,\text{km}$ long, calculate the minimum constant acceleration required for takeoff from rest.
questions.explanation: Using $v_f^2 = v_i^2 + 2ad$ with $v_i = 0$, $v_f = 85\,\text{m/s}$, and $d = 1200\,\text{m}$, we have $85^2 = 2a(1200) \Rightarrow a = 7225/2400 \approx 3.01\,\text{m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A hammer is dropped from rest from a scaffold $60\,\text{m}$ high. Calculate the time it takes to reach a point $10\,\text{m}$ above the ground. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$ and neglect air resistance)
questions.explanation: The hammer falls a distance of $50\,\text{m}$. Using $s = \frac{1}{2}gt^2$, we have $50 = 4.9t^2 \Rightarrow t = \sqrt{50/4.9} \approx 3.19\,\text{s}$.

questions.question: A projectile is launched vertically upward from the ground and returns to its starting point in $6.4\,\text{s}$. Determine the maximum height attained by the object. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$ and neglect air resistance)
questions.explanation: Time to reach maximum height is half the total flight time: $t_{\text{up}} = 3.2\,\text{s}$. Initial velocity $u = gt = 9.8(3.2) = 31.36\,\text{m/s}$. Maximum height $H = u^2/(2g) = (31.36^2)/(19.6) \approx 50.2\,\text{m}$.

questions.question: A ball is kicked from ground level at an angle of $55^{\circ}$ above the horizontal with an initial speed of $18\,\text{m/s}$. Determine the total time of flight. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$ and neglect air resistance)
questions.explanation: Initial vertical velocity $v_{y0} = 18\sin55^{\circ} \approx 18(0.8192) = 14.74\,\text{m/s}$. Time of flight $t = 2v_{y0}/g = 2(14.74)/9.8 \approx 29.48/9.8 \approx 3.01\,\text{s}$.

questions.question: A stunt driver drives a car off a flat-topped cliff at a horizontal speed of $25\,\text{m/s}$. If the car lands $65\,\text{m}$ from the base of the cliff, calculate the height of the cliff. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$ and neglect air resistance)
questions.explanation: Time of fall: $t = \text{horizontal distance} / v_x = 65/25 = 2.6\,\text{s}$. Height $h = \frac{1}{2}gt^2 = 4.9(2.6^2) = 4.9(6.76) \approx 33.1\,\text{m}$.

questions.question: Calculate the vertical and horizontal components of the velocity for a projectile launched with an initial speed of $30\,\text{m/s}$ at an angle of $20^{\circ}$ above the horizontal.
questions.explanation: $v_x = v\cos\theta = 30\cos20^{\circ} \approx 30(0.9397) = 28.2\,\text{m/s}$. $v_y = v\sin\theta = 30\sin20^{\circ} \approx 30(0.3420) = 10.3\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: A river flows due South at $2.5\,\text{m/s}$. A boat capable of moving at $5.0\,\text{m/s}$ in still water heads due East across the river. Calculate the magnitude of the velocity of the boat relative to an observer on the shore.
questions.explanation: The boat's velocity relative to water is east, and the water's velocity is south. These are perpendicular, so the resultant speed is $v = \sqrt{5.0^2 + 2.5^2} = \sqrt{25 + 6.25} = \sqrt{31.25} \approx 5.59\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: Car A travels due North at $60\,\text{km/h}$ and Car B travels due South at $90\,\text{km/h}$. Calculate the velocity of Car A as observed from Car B (i.e., the relative velocity $\vec{v}_{A/B}$).
questions.explanation: Taking North as positive: $\vec{v}_{A/B} = \vec{v}_A - \vec{v}_B = 60 - (-90) = 150\,\text{km/h}$ directed North.

questions.question: A $1200\,\text{kg}$ car is traveling at $22\,\text{m/s}$ when the brakes are applied, providing a constant friction force of $5000\,\text{N}$. Calculate the time taken for the car to come to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: Deceleration $a = -F/m = -5000/1200 \approx -4.167\,\text{m/s}^2$. Using $v_f = v_i + at$ with $v_f = 0$, we have $0 = 22 - 4.167t \Rightarrow t = 22/4.167 \approx 5.28\,\text{s}$.

questions.question: A $15\,\text{kg}$ box is being pulled across a horizontal floor by a constant force of $45\,\text{N}$ directed horizontally. If the box accelerates at $2.2\,\text{m/s}^2$, calculate the coefficient of kinetic friction between the box and the floor. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: Net force $F_{\text{net}} = ma = 15(2.2) = 33\,\text{N}$. Frictional force $f_k = F_{\text{applied}} - F_{\text{net}} = 45 - 33 = 12\,\text{N}$. Normal force $N = mg = 147\,\text{N}$. Thus $\mu_k = f_k/N = 12/147 \approx 0.082$.

questions.question: Calculate the magnitude of the net force required to accelerate a $2.5\,\text{kg}$ object from $4.0\,\text{m/s}$ to $16.0\,\text{m/s}$ over a distance of $10.0\,\text{m}$.
questions.explanation: Using $v_f^2 = v_i^2 + 2a\Delta x$, we have $16^2 = 4^2 + 2a(10) \Rightarrow 256 = 16 + 20a \Rightarrow a = 240/20 = 12\,\text{m/s}^2$. Then $F = ma = 2.5(12) = 30\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: A $12\,\text{kg}$ block is held in place on a $25^{\circ}$ frictionless incline by a horizontal force applied to the block. Calculate the magnitude of this horizontal force. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: From the force equilibrium parallel to the incline: $F\cos25^{\circ} = mg\sin25^{\circ}$. Thus $F = mg\tan25^{\circ} = 12(9.8)(0.4663) \approx 54.8\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: An object slides down a ramp inclined at $40^{\circ}$ to the horizontal. If the coefficient of kinetic friction between the object and the ramp is $0.22$, calculate the acceleration of the object. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)

A $2.0\,\text{kg}$ mass and a $4.0\,\text{kg}$ mass are connected by a light string that passes over a frictionless pulley. If the system is released from rest, calculate the tension in the string during the subsequent motion. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: Acceleration $a = \frac{(4-2)g}{4+2} = \frac{2(9.8)}{6} = 19.6/6 \approx 3.267\,\text{m/s}^2$. For the $2.0\,\text{kg}$ mass, $T - m_1g = m_1a \Rightarrow T = 2(9.8 + 3.267) \approx 26.1\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: A $10\,\text{kg}$ block on a horizontal table with coefficient of kinetic friction $\mu_k = 0.3$ is connected by a string over a pulley to a $5.0\,\text{kg}$ hanging mass. Determine the acceleration of the $10\,\text{kg}$ block. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: For the system: $F_{\text{net}} = m_2g - \mu_k m_1g = 5(9.8) - 0.3(10)(9.8) = 49 - 29.4 = 19.6\,\text{N}$. Total mass $m_{\text{total}} = 15\,\text{kg}$. Thus $a = 19.6/15 \approx 1.31\,\text{m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A $5.0\,\text{kg}$ mass is suspended by two strings. String 1 is horizontal and String 2 makes an angle of $60^{\circ}$ with the horizontal. Calculate the tension in String 2. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: Considering vertical equilibrium: the vertical component of tension in String 2 must balance the weight. Thus $T_2\sin60^{\circ} = mg = 49\,\text{N}$. Solving: $T_2 = 49/\sin60^{\circ} = 49/0.8660 \approx 56.6\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: A $70\,\text{kg}$ man stands on a bathroom scale in an elevator that is accelerating upward at $1.8\,\text{m/s}^2$. What is the scale reading expressed in kilograms (i.e., the apparent mass)? (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: The normal force (scale reading) is $N = m(g + a) = 70(9.8 + 1.8) = 70(11.6) = 812\,\text{N}$. Apparent mass = $N/g = 812/9.8 \approx 82.9\,\text{kg}$.

questions.question: An object moves in a circular path of radius $2.5\,\text{m}$ with a constant period of $4.0\,\text{s}$. Calculate the centripetal acceleration of the object.
questions.explanation: Speed $v = 2\pi r/T = 2\pi(2.5)/4.0 = 5\pi/4 \approx 3.927\,\text{m/s}$. Centripetal acceleration $a_c = v^2/r = (3.927)^2/2.5 \approx 15.42/2.5 \approx 6.17\,\text{m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A fan blade has a radius of $0.35\,\text{m}$ and rotates at $1200\,\text{RPM}$ (revolutions per minute). Calculate the tangential speed of the tip of the blade.
questions.explanation: Angular velocity $\omega = 1200 \times 2\pi/60 = 1200 \times 0.10472 \approx 40\pi\,\text{rad/s}$. Tangential speed $v = \omega r = 40\pi(0.35) = 14\pi \approx 44.0\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: A $0.30\,\text{kg}$ ball is attached to a $0.80\,\text{m}$ string and whirled in a vertical circle. Calculate the tension in the string at the top of the circle if the speed at that point is $4.5\,\text{m/s}$. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: At the top, the centripetal force is provided by the sum of tension and weight: $T + mg = mv^2/r$. Thus $T = m(v^2/r - g) = 0.30(4.5^2/0.80 - 9.8) = 0.30(25.31 - 9.8) \approx 4.65\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: A car of mass $1500\,\text{kg}$ passes over the crest of a hump-backed bridge. The bridge has a radius of curvature of $25\,\text{m}$ at the crest. Calculate the maximum speed the car can have without losing contact with the road. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: Losing contact occurs when the normal force becomes zero, meaning $mg$ alone provides the centripetal force: $mg = mv^2/r$. Thus $v = \sqrt{gr} = \sqrt{9.8 \times 25} = \sqrt{245} \approx 15.65\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: A $1000\,\text{kg}$ car rounds a flat, unbanked curve of radius $40\,\text{m}$ at a constant speed of $15\,\text{m/s}$. Calculate the minimum coefficient of static friction required to prevent the car from sliding. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: Friction provides the centripetal force: $\mu_s mg = mv^2/r$. Thus $\mu_s = v^2/(rg) = 225/(40 \times 9.8) = 225/392 \approx 0.57$.

questions.question: A $0.50\,\text{kg}$ mass is attached to a string and swung in a horizontal circle of radius $1.5\,\text{m}$ on a frictionless surface. If the string can withstand a maximum tension of $50\,\text{N}$, what is the maximum speed the mass can have?
questions.explanation: Tension provides the centripetal force: $T = mv^2/r$. Solving for $v$: $v = \sqrt{Tr/m} = \sqrt{50 \times 1.5 / 0.50} = \sqrt{150} \approx 12.25\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: Calculate the magnitude of the gravitational force between two students, each with a mass of $80\,\text{kg}$, sitting $1.5\,\text{m}$ apart. (Take $G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11}\,\text{N}\cdot\text{m}^2/\text{kg}^2$)
If the Earth were to shrink to half its current radius while maintaining the same mass, how would the acceleration due to gravity ($g$) at the surface change?
questions.explanation: Surface gravity is $g = GM/R^2$. If $R$ becomes $R/2$, then $g' = GM/(R/2)^2 = 4GM/R^2 = 4g$.

questions.question: A $20\,\text{kg}$ crate is pushed $15\,\text{m}$ across a level floor where a constant friction force of $60\,\text{N}$ acts. Calculate the work done by the friction force.
questions.explanation: Work done by a constant force is $W = \vec{F} \cdot \vec{d} = Fd\cos\theta$. Since friction opposes motion, $\theta = 180^{\circ}$ and $\cos180^{\circ} = -1$. Thus $W = -60 \times 15 = -900\,\text{J}$.

questions.question: A $1.0\,\text{kg}$ object is initially moving at $5.0\,\text{m/s}$. It is then acted upon by a net force of $12\,\text{N}$ in the direction of motion over a distance of $3.0\,\text{m}$. Calculate the final kinetic energy of the object.
questions.explanation: Initial kinetic energy $KE_i = \frac{1}{2}mv_i^2 = 0.5(1.0)(25) = 12.5\,\text{J}$. Work done by net force $W = Fd = 12(3.0) = 36\,\text{J}$. By the work-energy theorem, $KE_f = KE_i + W = 12.5 + 36 = 48.5\,\text{J}$.

questions.question: Calculate the magnitude of the constant braking force required to bring a $1400\,\text{kg}$ car traveling at $20\,\text{m/s}$ to a complete stop over a distance of $40\,\text{m}$.
questions.explanation: Initial kinetic energy $KE_i = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = 0.5(1400)(400) = 280,000\,\text{J}$. Work done by braking force is $W = -Fd = \Delta KE = 0 - 280,000 = -280,000\,\text{J}$. Thus $F = 280,000/40 = 7000\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: A $0.5\,\text{kg}$ pendulum bob is released from rest at a height of $0.15\,\text{m}$ above its equilibrium position. Calculate its speed as it passes through the equilibrium position. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$ and neglect friction)
questions.explanation: By conservation of mechanical energy, $mgh = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 \Rightarrow v = \sqrt{2gh} = \sqrt{2(9.8)(0.15)} = \sqrt{2.94} \approx 1.71\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: A $50\,\text{kg}$ crate slides down a $10\,\text{m}$ long ramp that is inclined at $30^{\circ}$ to the horizontal. It reaches the bottom of the ramp with a speed of $6.0\,\text{m/s}$. Calculate the amount of mechanical energy dissipated as heat due to friction. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: Vertical height $h = 10\sin30^{\circ} = 5\,\text{m}$. Initial potential energy $PE_i = mgh = 50(9.8)(5) = 2450\,\text{J}$. Final kinetic energy $KE_f = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = 0.5(50)(36) = 900\,\text{J}$. Energy lost $= 2450 - 900 = 1550\,\text{J}$.

questions.question: A $1500\,\text{W}$ electric heater is used for $10\,\text{minutes}$. Calculate the total electrical energy consumed in Joules.
questions.explanation: Time $t = 10\,\text{minutes} = 600\,\text{s}$. Energy $E = Pt = 1500 \times 600 = 900,000\,\text{J}$.

questions.question: A motor pulls a $200\,\text{kg}$ block up a $20^{\circ}$ frictionless incline at a constant speed of $2.5\,\text{m/s}$. Calculate the power output of the motor. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: At constant speed, the force exerted by the motor equals the component of weight down the incline: $F = mg\sin20^{\circ} = 200(9.8)(0.3420) \approx 670.3\,\text{N}$. Power $P = Fv = 670.3(2.5) \approx 1676\,\text{W}$.

questions.question: A spring has a spring constant of $450\,\text{N/m}$. Calculate the work required to stretch the spring from an extension of $0.10\,\text{m}$ to an extension of $0.20\,\text{m}$.
questions.explanation: Work done on a spring equals the change in elastic potential energy: $W = \frac{1}{2}k(x_2^2 - x_1^2) = 0.5(450)(0.04 - 0.01) = 225(0.03) = 6.75\,\text{J}$.

questions.question: A vertical spring with spring constant $k = 200\,\text{N/m}$ is compressed by $0.15\,\text{m}$ from its equilibrium position. If a $0.25\,\text{kg}$ mass is placed on top of the compressed spring and released, calculate the maximum height reached by the mass above the release point. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: Elastic potential energy stored: $E = \frac{1}{2}kx^2 = 0.5(200)(0.0225) = 2.25\,\text{J}$. This energy converts entirely to gravitational potential energy at maximum height: $mgh = 2.25$, so $h = 2.25/(0.25 \times 9.8) = 2.25/2.45 \approx 0.92\,\text{m}$.

questions.question: A $0.50\,\text{kg}$ ball moving north at $8.0\,\text{m/s}$ collides head-on with a $0.30\,\text{kg}$ ball moving south at $4.0\,\text{m/s}$. If the collision is perfectly inelastic (they stick together), find the final velocity of the combined mass.
questions.explanation: Take north as positive. Initial momentum $p_i = 0.50(8.0) + 0.30(-4.0) = 4.0 - 1.2 = 2.8\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m/s}$. Total mass $m_{\text{total}} = 0.80\,\text{kg}$. Final velocity $v_f = p_i/m_{\text{total}} = 2.8/0.80 = 3.5\,\text{m/s}$ directed north.

questions.question: In a perfectly elastic head-on collision, a $2.0\,\text{kg}$ mass moving at $10\,\text{m/s}$ strikes a stationary $8.0\,\text{kg}$ mass. Calculate the velocity of the $2.0\,\text{kg}$ mass after the collision.
questions.explanation: For an elastic collision, the final velocity of mass $m_1$ is $v_{1f} = \frac{m_1 - m_2}{m_1 + m_2} v_{1i} = \frac{2.0 - 8.0}{2.0 + 8.0}(10) = \frac{-6}{10}(10) = -6\,\text{m/s}$. The negative sign indicates it rebounds in the opposite direction.

questions.question: A $5.0\,\text{kg}$ object initially at rest explodes into three pieces. Piece A has mass $1.0\,\text{kg}$ and moves east at $10\,\text{m/s}$. Piece B has mass $2.0\,\text{kg}$ and moves west at $5.0\,\text{m/s}$. Calculate the velocity of Piece C, which has a mass of $2.0\,\text{kg}$.
questions.explanation: Conservation of momentum requires the total momentum after the explosion to be zero (since initial momentum was zero). Take east as positive: $0 = m_Av_A + m_Bv_B + m_Cv_C = 1.0(10) + 2.0(-5) + 2.0v_C = 10 - 10 + 2v_C = 2v_C$. Thus $v_C = 0\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: Two resistors, $15\,\Omega$ and $R$, are connected in series with a $45\,\text{V}$ battery. If the current in the circuit is $1.5\,\text{A}$, find the value of $R$.
questions.explanation: Total resistance $R_{\text{total}} = V/I = 45/1.5 = 30\,\Omega$. Since $R_{\text{total}} = 15 + R$, we have $R = 30 - 15 = 15\,\Omega$.

questions.question: Three resistors with resistances $20\,\Omega$, $30\,\Omega$, and $50\,\Omega$ are connected in series. If the total voltage supplied to the circuit is $200\,\text{V}$, calculate the potential difference across the $30\,\Omega$ resistor.
questions.explanation: Total resistance $R_{\text{total}} = 20 + 30 + 50 = 100\,\Omega$. Current $I = V/R_{\text{total}} = 200/100 = 2\,\text{A}$. Voltage across the $30\,\Omega$ resistor is $V = IR = 2 \times 30 = 60\,\text{V}$.

questions.question: A $12\,\Omega$ resistor and a $6\,\Omega$ resistor are connected in parallel. Calculate the current through the $12\,\Omega$ resistor if the total current entering the parallel combination is $9.0\,\text{A}$.
questions.explanation: The equivalent resistance is $R_{\text{eq}} = (12 \times 6)/(12 + 6) = 72/18 = 4\,\Omega$. Voltage across the parallel combination is $V = I_{\text{total}}R_{\text{eq}} = 9.0(4) = 36\,\text{V}$. Current through the $12\,\Omega$ resistor is $I_{12} = V/12 = 36/12 = 3.0\,\text{A}$.

questions.question: Three resistors with resistances $10\,\Omega$, $20\,\Omega$, and $40\,\Omega$ are connected in parallel. Calculate the equivalent resistance.

A $10\,\Omega$ resistor is connected in series with a parallel combination of two $15\,\Omega$ resistors. If the circuit is connected to a $35\,\text{V}$ source, calculate the total current drawn from the source.
questions.explanation: Equivalent resistance of the parallel combination: $R_p = (15 \times 15)/(15 + 15) = 225/30 = 7.5\,\Omega$. Total resistance $R_{\text{total}} = 10 + 7.5 = 17.5\,\Omega$. Current $I = V/R_{\text{total}} = 35/17.5 = 2\,\text{A}$.

questions.question: Calculate the total equivalent resistance of a circuit consisting of two $20\,\Omega$ resistors in parallel, connected in series with two $10\,\Omega$ resistors that are themselves in series.
questions.explanation: The two $20\,\Omega$ resistors in parallel have an equivalent resistance of $10\,\Omega$. The two $10\,\Omega$ resistors in series have an equivalent resistance of $20\,\Omega$. The total resistance is $10 + 20 = 30\,\Omega$.

questions.question: A wave on a string has a frequency of $60\,\text{Hz}$ and a speed of $30\,\text{m/s}$. Calculate the phase difference between two points on the string that are separated by a distance of $10\,\text{cm}$.
questions.explanation: Wavelength $\lambda = v/f = 30/60 = 0.5\,\text{m}$. Phase difference $\Delta\phi = (2\pi/\lambda)\Delta x = (2\pi/0.5)(0.10) = 4\pi(0.10) = 0.4\pi\,\text{rad} = 72^{\circ}$.

questions.question: The speed of a transverse wave on a string is $150\,\text{m/s}$. If the linear mass density of the string is $0.02\,\text{kg/m}$, calculate the tension in the string.
questions.explanation: Wave speed $v = \sqrt{T/\mu}$, where $T$ is tension and $\mu$ is linear mass density. Solving for $T$: $T = \mu v^2 = 0.02 \times (150)^2 = 0.02 \times 22500 = 450\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: A stationary observer hears a frequency of $520\,\text{Hz}$ from a sound source moving directly toward them at $25\,\text{m/s}$. Calculate the actual frequency of the source. (Assume the speed of sound in air is $340\,\text{m/s}$)
questions.explanation: For a source moving toward a stationary observer, $f' = f\left(\frac{v}{v - v_s}\right)$. Solving for $f$: $f = f'\left(\frac{v - v_s}{v}\right) = 520\left(\frac{340 - 25}{340}\right) = 520(315/340) \approx 520(0.9265) \approx 482\,\text{Hz}$.

questions.question: Two speakers are placed $4.0\,\text{m}$ apart and are emitting a $170\,\text{Hz}$ tone in phase. An observer stands at a point located $5.0\,\text{m}$ from one speaker and $8.0\,\text{m}$ from the other. Determine whether the observer hears a loud or soft sound (assume the speed of sound is $340\,\text{m/s}$).
questions.explanation: Wavelength $\lambda = v/f = 340/170 = 2\,\text{m}$. Path difference $\Delta r = |8.0 - 5.0| = 3.0\,\text{m}$. $\Delta r/\lambda = 3.0/2.0 = 1.5$, which is a half-integer multiple of the wavelength. This corresponds to destructive interference, so the sound will be soft.

questions.question: A pipe open at both ends has a length of $1.2\,\text{m}$. Calculate the frequency of the second harmonic produced by this pipe. (Assume the speed of sound in air is $340\,\text{m/s}$)
questions.explanation: For an open pipe, the frequency of the $n$th harmonic is $f_n = nv/(2L)$. For the second harmonic ($n=2$), $f_2 = 2(340)/(2 \times 1.2) = 340/1.2 \approx 283\,\text{Hz}$.

questions.question: Two identical pulses travel toward each other on a string. If each pulse has a maximum displacement of $2.5\,\text{cm}$, what is the maximum displacement of the string when the pulses completely overlap?
questions.explanation: According to the principle of superposition, when two identical pulses overlap completely, they undergo constructive interference. The maximum displacement is the sum of the individual amplitudes: $2.5 + 2.5 = 5.0\,\text{cm}$.
